科幻小说

Science Fiction

麻省理工学院出版社基本知识系列

雪莉·文特

系列前言

Series Foreword

麻省理工学院出版社的“基本知识”系列丛书提供通俗易懂、简洁明了、制作精美的袖珍书籍，涵盖当前热门话题。本系列丛书由顶尖思想家撰写，涵盖文化、历史、科学和技术等各个领域的专家概述。

The MIT Press Essential Knowledge series offers accessible, concise, beautifully produced pocket-size books on topics of current interest. Written by leading thinkers, the books in this series deliver expert overviews of subjects that range from the cultural and the historical to the scientific and the technical.

在当今这个信息即时满足的时代，我们唾手可得各种观点、合理化解释和肤浅的描述。而那些能够帮助我们对世界形成原则性理解的基础知识却难以获得。《基本知识》系列丛书正是满足了这一需求。这些紧凑的书籍为非专业人士整合了专业主题，并通过基础知识探讨关键话题，为读者提供了理解复杂思想的切入点。

In today’s era of instant information gratification, we have ready access to opinions, rationalizations, and superficial descriptions. Much harder to come by is the foundational knowledge that informs a principled understanding of the world. Essential Knowledge books fill that need. Synthesizing specialized subject matter for nonspecialists and engaging critical topics through fundamentals, each of these compact volumes offers readers a point of access to complex ideas.

1

1

简介：谁的科幻小说？

Introduction: Whose Science Fiction?

世界正变得越来越像科幻小说，这已是不言而喻的真理。从能与我们对话的手机（让《星际迷航》粉丝想起三录仪），到转基因食品，再到物联网和自动驾驶汽车的前景，工业化国家的人们生活在科技的洪流之中。因此，日常生活有时仿佛置身于20世纪二三十年代通俗科幻小说的场景之中——要么是一个由科技完善的世界，体现在诸如1939年世界博览会等以“明日世界”为主题的事件中；要么是一个反乌托邦的噩梦，就像奥尔德斯·赫胥黎的《美丽新世界》（1932年）一样。科幻小说将如何帮助我们概念化和应对一个开始变得像科幻小说的世界——既奇妙又邪恶？本书概述了科幻小说如何应对科学技术塑造和改变人类生活的方式。正如这里介绍的那样，该类型是一种工具思考并干预世界。本书探讨的是科幻小说的潜力，而非重要作家和作品的目录。

It has become axiomatic to say that the world is becoming like science fiction (sf). From mobile phones that speak to us (reminding Star Trek fans of tricorders), to genetically modified foods, to the Internet of Things and the promise of self-driving cars, people in industrialized nations live immersed in technology. Daily life can thus at times seem like visions from the pulp sf of the 1920s and 1930s—either a world perfected by technology, manifested in events such as the 1939 World’s Fair, with its theme “The World of Tomorrow”; or a dystopian nightmare, such as Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World (1932). How might sf help us conceptualize and respond to a world that has begun to resemble sf, in ways both marvelous and malign? This book provides an overview of how sf grapples with the ways that science and technology shape and change human lives. As introduced here, the genre is a tool for thinking about and intervening in the world. This book is about what science fiction can do, not a catalogue of important authors and titles.

这一类型是思考和干预世界的工具。这本书探讨的是科幻小说的潜力。

The genre is a tool for thinking about and intervening in the world. This book is about what science fiction can do.

关于如何准确定义科幻小说以及如何确定其起源，存在许多相互矛盾的说法。一些人认为，所有关于科学的思辨性写作都有悠久的传统，可以追溯到约翰尼斯·开普勒的《梦境》（1608 年）甚至更早。另一些人则将其与乌托邦写作联系起来，始于托马斯·莫尔的《乌托邦》（1516 年）；后来的乌托邦作品提供了对未来社会的展望，例如爱德华·贝拉米的《回顾过去，2000-1887》（1888 年）和威廉·莫里斯的《乌有乡消息》（1890 年）。还有一些人认为赫伯特·乔治·威尔斯的科学爱情小说和儒勒·凡尔纳的《奇异航海记》是这一流派的“鼻祖”，而这一流派的起源与 19 世纪末 20 世纪初科学在西方文化中占据主导地位的时期密不可分。布莱恩·奥尔迪斯在其关于科幻小说流派的内幕史著作《十亿年的狂欢》（1973年）中，颇具影响力地将玛丽·雪莱的《弗兰肯斯坦》（1818年）称为第一部科幻小说，这部作品将最新的科学创新与人文主义的社会伦理思考传统融为一体。一种流行趋势将科幻小说的起源追溯到20世纪20年代的美国通俗小说，主要是雨果·根斯巴克的《惊奇故事》，该书吸引了当时新兴的、充满热情的实验者和技术人员群体。根斯巴克推广了“科幻小说”一词，这是他最初提出的“科学化”的一个更简单的版本。在《惊奇故事》 （1926 年）创刊号中，他宣布这将成为一种百年来“新型”的小说，它将在文学中开辟一条新道路，并且“也在不断进步”。1对于最初的粉丝群体来说，根斯巴克时代是奠基性的，他的技术爱好者言论是这一流派的核心，但他的观点仅代表了复杂传统的一个方面。

There are many competing claims regarding precisely how to define sf and how to determine when the genre began. Some argue for a long tradition of all speculative writing about science, dating back to Johannes Kepler’s Somnium (1608) or even earlier. Others link it to utopian writing, beginning with Thomas More’s Utopia (1516); later utopias offered visions of future societies in examples such as Edward Bellamy’s Looking Backward, 2000–1887 (1888) and William Morris’s News from Nowhere (1890). Still others see H. G. Wells’s scientific romances and Jules Verne’s Voyages extraordinaires as the “fathers” of a genre whose origins are inextricably linked to science becoming culturally dominant in Western cultures during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. In his insider history of the genre, Billion Year Spree (1973), Brian Aldiss influentially dubs Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein (1818) the first sf novel, a work that fuses the latest innovations in science with a humanist tradition of thinking about society and ethics. A popular trend dates sf’s origin to the American pulps of the 1920s, chiefly Hugo Gernsback’s Amazing Stories, which tapped into an emergent, enthusiastic community of experimenters and technicians. Gernsback is responsible for popularizing the term science fiction, a less complicated version of his original “scientification.” In the first issue of Amazing Stories (1926), he announced this was to be a “new sort” of fiction for a century that would chart a new path in literature and “in progress as well.”1 For original fan communities, the Gernsback era was foundational, and his technophilic pronouncements are the core of the genre, but his view represents only one facet of a complex tradition.

本书并不打算详细阐述科幻小说的历史，也不打算对科幻小说的起源发表任何看法，而是着眼于它们共同的核心：对不同世界的设想，以及这种变化可能带来的可能性。我的目标既不是提供这一流派的详细历史，也不是提供其最重要作品的综合清单。相反，我将沿袭约翰·里德的观点，关注科幻小说的作用，以及不同类型的读者如何以不同的方式对科幻小说进行描述，以达到多种目的。2我计划描绘出各种作者和读者是如何对科幻小说进行唤起和使用的，并概述这一流派如何——并且将继续——有助于理解工业化、技术化社会中的日常生活。

Rather than elaborate this history or take a position on the origins of science fiction, this book focuses on what they share at their core: a vision of the world made otherwise and the possibilities that might flow from such change. My goal is to provide neither a detailed history of the genre nor a comprehensive listing of its most important works. Rather, following John Rieder, I am interested in focusing on what science fiction can do, how it has been described by a variety of constituencies in distinct ways for multiple ends.2 I plan to chart how sf is evoked and used by a range of authors and audiences and sketch an overview of how the genre has been—and continues to be—useful for grasping daily life in industrialized, technologized societies.

尽管对于“科幻”一词的含义可能没有精确的界定，但某些图像或叙述会立即浮现在脑海中：通过火箭飞船或飞行汽车增强机动性；沉浸在数字化环境中，从虚拟娱乐到将一个人的意识数字化转移到新的身体；对未来的想法，其中可能包括截然不同的公民，如具有自我意识的机器人或基因改造人，甚至外星人。因此，一组图像传达了科幻小说的核心，即使其边缘的界限模糊不清，不同的社区在宣称这一标签并试图定义它所描述的类型时心中有不同的想法，这使得情况变得更加复杂。例如，许多科幻迷和学者认为，其印刷形式不可避免地比媒体版本更加微妙，这种说法让 21 世纪的观众感到困惑，对他们来说，“科幻小说”往往等同于广为人知的媒体文本，如《星际迷航》，自 1966 年以来，该片已在电视或电影屏幕上反复播放。

Although there may be no precise demarcation of what the term science fiction denotes, certain images or narratives immediately come to mind: enhanced mobility via rocket ships or flying cars; immersion in digitized environments, from virtual entertainments to perhaps digitally transferring one’s consciousness to a new body; and the idea of the future, which may include radically different citizens such as self-conscious robots or genetically modified people, perhaps even aliens. A set of images thus conveys the core of science fiction, even if the boundaries at its edges are indistinct, a situation further complicated by the fact that different communities have diverse ideas in mind when they claim the label and try to define the genre it describes. Many fans and scholars of sf, for example, argue that its print form is inevitably more nuanced than media versions, a claim confusing to twenty-first-century audiences for whom “science fiction” is often synonymous with widely known media texts such as Star Trek, which has been on television or film screens in myriad iterations since 1966.

玛格丽特·阿特伍德曾声称，她写的是推想小说而非科幻小说，因为她是从已知科学中进行推断，而不是创造未来版本。这一说法广为流传，也体现了这种混淆：不仅大多数读者会认出她最著名的作品—— 《使女的故事》（1985 年）和《疯狂亚当》三部曲（2003-2013 年）——是科幻小说，而且大多数科幻小说从业者和粉丝也会同意，很多（并非全部！）科幻小说同样是从已知科学中进行推断。3事实上，许多人交替使用推想小说和科幻小说这两个术语，因为他们认识到，尽管有这样的标签，但科学与科幻小说之间的关系既不简单也不直接。4特殊定义因此，围绕类型界限的细枝末节的争论不会让我们走得太远。科幻小说更应该被概念化为一种趋势，加里·沃尔夫将这种现象描述为一种融入并渗透到当今许多文化生产中的风格。5小伊斯特凡·西塞里-罗奈认为，我们应该将科幻小说理解为一种模式而非一种类型，一种体验近几十年来已变得常态化的世界的方式。他使用“科幻性”一词来描述这种感知和评价事物的方式，“仿佛它们是科幻作品的一部分” 。6

Margaret Atwood’s widely circulated claim that she writes speculative rather than science fiction, because she extrapolates from known science rather than inventing futuristic versions of it, embodies the confusion: not only would most readers recognize her most widely known works—The Handmaid’s Tale (1985) and the MaddAddam trilogy (2003–2013)—as science fiction, but most practitioners and fans of science fiction would also agree that much (not all!) sf similarly extrapolates from known science.3 Indeed, many people use the terms speculative fiction and science fiction interchangeably, recognizing that, despite the label, the relationship between science and science fiction is neither simple nor direct.4 Idiosyncratic definitions and squabbles about the minutiae of genre borders will thus not get us very far. Science fiction is better conceptualized as a tendency, a phenomenon Gary Wolfe describes as a style that evaporates into and permeates much cultural production today.5 Istvan Csiscery-Ronay Jr. argues that we should understand sf as a mode rather than a genre, a way of experiencing the world that has become normalized in recent decades. He uses the term “science fictionality” to describe this way of perceiving and evaluating things as “if they were aspects of a work of science fiction.”6

我倾向于将科幻小说理解为一种文化形式，它提供了一种“日常”语言，用于思考和回应21世纪的日常生活。它与科学以及社会技术文化主题（星际旅行、数字化体验和通信、基因改造、人工智能等等）的互动是隐喻性的，无论它所设想的世界是否真实存在。科幻小说探讨科学技术对人类经验、价值观和生活方式的影响，即使它通过科学告诉我们不可能实现的场景来探讨这些问题，它也会运用这些象征来评论我们日常生活中那些原本被忽视的方面。例如，阿特伍德认为，威尔斯在《世界大战》（1897）中描绘的不可能出现的火星入侵者，使他的创作理念与凡尔纳对……的似是而非的设想有着根本的不同。现有交通技术的更强大版本。然而，从另一个角度来看，我们可以看到威尔斯与凡尔纳一样，对当代社会技术文化的关注，他以更高级的火星文明征服伦敦的隐喻，对科学技术在殖民历史中所扮演的角色提出了质疑。7

My preference is to understand science fiction as a cultural form that offers an “everyday” language for thinking about and responding to daily life in twenty-first century. Its engagement with science and with the motifs of sociotechnical culture—interplanetary travel, digitized experience and communications, genomic modification, artificial intelligence (AI), and more—is metaphorical, whether the worlds it posits might actually happen or not. The genre asks questions about the impact of science and technology on human experience, values, and ways of living, and even when it explores these issues through scenarios that science tells us are impossible, the genre uses such symbols to comment upon otherwise unnoticed aspects of our ordinary world. For example, Atwood suggests that the impossible Martian invaders in Wells’s The War of the Worlds (1897) make his creative enterprise fundamentally different from Verne’s plausible visions of more powerful versions of existing transportation technologies. From a different angle, however, we can see that Wells engages contemporary sociotechnical culture just as much as Verne does, using the metaphor of a superior Martian civilization conquering London to raise questions about the role science and technology have played in colonial history.7

这些关于术语的争论凸显了科幻界自使用“科幻小说”这个标签以来一直存在的一个核心矛盾：科幻小说主要是一种与合理的科学推断有关的体裁，甚至可能与教育公众的科学素养有关？还是它主要是一种社会变革文学，经常使用未来技术来表明故事发生在不同的世界，但对社会变革而非科学变革更感兴趣？在《惊奇故事》创刊十年后，由根斯巴克发起的带有科学色彩的科幻小说联盟粉丝团分裂了。一个新的组织出现了，最初名为科幻小说政治发展委员会，后来更名为未来主义，其成员包括弗雷德里克·波尔、朱迪思·梅里尔、唐纳德·A·沃尔海姆和年轻的艾萨克·阿西莫夫等有影响力的作家和编辑，并呼吁科幻小说少关注新奇的小玩意，多参与社会批判。持相反观点的保守派粉丝 Sam Moskowitz 创立了 New Fandom，致力于“硬”或专注于科学的科幻小说，对社会变革几乎毫无兴趣。科幻小说自诞生之日起，既包含以科学为中心的推断，也包含对未来政治的展望——而科幻从业者们也曾争论，究竟哪种元素才是该类型小说的标志性特征。

These struggles over terminology illuminate one of the central tensions that has shaped the sf community as long as we have used this label: Is science fiction predominantly a genre that has to do with plausible scientific extrapolation, perhaps even with educating the public in scientific literacy? Or is it predominantly a literature of social change, often using futuristic technologies to establish that its stories take place in different worlds, but remaining more interested in social than scientific change? Within a decade of the first issue of Amazing Stories, the science-inflected Science Fiction League fan group launched by Gernsback fragmented. A new organization emerged, originally called the Committee for the Political Advancement of Science Fiction, later the Futurisms, whose members included influential authors and editors such as Frederik Pohl, Judith Merril, Donald A. Wollheim, and a young Isaac Asimov, and called for sf to be less interested in new gadgets and more engaged in social critique. Claiming the opposite, conservative fan Sam Moskowitz founded New Fandom, dedicated to a vision of “hard” or scientifically engaged sf that had little interest in social transformation. From its very beginnings, sf has included both science-focused extrapolations and politically engaged visions of the future—and arguments among its practitioners over which element was more definitive of the genre.

约翰·W·坎贝尔（John W. Campbell）在 1937 年至 1973 年期间担任核心杂志《惊人的科幻小说》（Astounding Science-Fiction）的主编，在其极具影响力的编辑领导下，一种技术官僚版本的硬科幻在二十世纪中叶占据了主导地位，塑造了人们对该类型的长期看法，而坎贝尔主编的早期时期后来被誉为黄金时代。不可否认，坎贝尔强有力的干预和固执的观点是美国科幻兴起的关键力量，但他的影响是开创了黄金时代，还是给该领域带来了“有史以来最严重的灾难”，仍是争论的焦点。8在20 世纪 60 年代和 70 年代，一群自称“新浪潮”的艺术家，与当时的法国新浪潮电影运动和更广泛的超现实主义保持一致，努力推动该类型朝着类似的新美学和主题发展，从而引发了该领域另一场保守的反应——等等。科幻小说不断地被发明和重新发明，有时更多地依赖于它与科学推断的联系，有时则强调它的文学性和挑战我们如何看待社会世界的形式能力。

Under the influential editorship of John W. Campbell, in charge of the central magazine Astounding Science-Fiction from 1937–1973, a technocratic version of hard sf dominated the field mid-twentieth century, shaping long-term perceptions of the genre when the early years of Campbell’s editorship subsequently became canonized as the Golden Age. Campbell’s strong interventions and rigid views were undeniably a key force in shaping the emergence of American sf, but whether his influence established a Golden Age or was the “worst disaster ever to hit” the field remains a matter of debate.8 In the 1960s and 1970s, a group of artists calling themselves the New Wave, thereby aligning themselves with the contemporary French Nouvelle Vague film movement and surrealism more generally, made efforts to push the genre toward similarly new aesthetics and themes, prompting another conservative reaction within the field—and so on. Science fiction is continually invented and reinvented, at times leaning more strongly on its connections to scientific extrapolation, at others emphasizing its literary qualities and formal capacity to challenge how we see the social world.

从一开始，科幻小说就既包含以科学为中心的推断，也包含政治参与的未来愿景。

From its very beginnings, sf has included both science-focused extrapolations and politically engaged visions of the future.

因此，要理解科幻小说的本质，就必须理解其核心在于科学推断与社会变革之间的张力。科幻小说运用多种美学风格和主题视角，探索世界原本可能的样子。我使用“sf”这个缩写词并非出于简写，而是反映了我的观点：以“科幻小说”或“思辨小说”为标签的文本密切相关。事实上，“思辨”一词的含义，即沉思或推测，恰如其分地体现了科幻小说对科学和技术的态度。

Grasping what science fiction is, then, requires understanding that this tension between scientific extrapolation and social change lies at its heart. It adopts a range of aesthetic styles and thematic preoccupations as it explores how the world might be otherwise. My use of the acronym sf is not merely shorthand but reflects my sense that texts circulating under either label—science fiction or speculative fiction—are closely related. Indeed, the meaning of the term “speculative” as involving contemplation or conjecture aptly captures the approach to science and technology adopted by science fiction.

在学术研究中，基于乌托邦研究的定义虽然也受到了挑战，但仍然具有影响力。最知名的是达科·苏文（Darko Suvin）的观点，他认为科幻小说是“认知疏离的文学”，9 这一观点是在与贝托尔特·布莱希特（Bertolt Brecht）和恩内斯特·布洛赫（Ernest Bloch）的文化批评著作对话中发展起来的。所有人都对艺术的力量感兴趣，艺术能够将我们从陈旧的联想或认知中唤醒，让我们不再仅仅看到日常世界本身不证自明的自然性，而是将其视为众多偶然可能性中的一种，是历史选择的产物。苏文认为，最好的科幻小说与社会批判的变革性项目相契合，并指出科幻小说疏离的认知维度（他将其与科学联系起来）确保了其富有想象力的愿景与物质世界中的实践可能性紧密相连。因此，对他而言，科幻小说具有政治赋能作用，并以现实世界的变革为导向，而与之相反他认为奇幻作品是故弄玄虚，故不予理会。尽管这种僵化的体裁净化在近期的批评中遭到否定——事实上，它从未以实证的方式描述过科幻作品的主体——但科幻体裁关乎变革的观点依然存在。然而，苏文认为科幻必然会体现那些被主流文化排斥的群体的视角，这一观点已被彻底推翻。10

In academic study, definitions based in utopian studies have been influential, if also challenged. Most recognizable is Darko Suvin’s contention that science fiction is “the literature of cognitive estrangement,”9 developed in dialogue with works of cultural critique by Bertolt Brecht and Ernest Bloch. All are interested in the power of art to jar us out of commonplace associations or perceptions, to see the quotidian world not in all its self-evident naturalness but as one contingent possibility among many, the product of historical choice. Suvin argues that the best sf aligns with a transformative project of social critique and suggests that the cognitive dimension of sf’s estrangement, which he correlates with science, ensures that its imaginative visions remain tethered to a practical possibility in the material world. For him, sf is thus politically enabling and oriented toward real-world change, in contrast to works of fantasy, which he dismisses as mystifications. Although this rigid genre purification has been rejected in recent criticism—and indeed, never empirically described the bulk of sf in any case—the idea that the genre is about change persists. Suvin’s ideal that sf would necessarily embody the perspective of those socially excluded from dominant culture, however, has been thoroughly debunked.10

另一位对科幻有影响力的学术概念来自弗雷德里克·詹姆逊，他同样对科幻体裁能够提供不同的、理想中更美好世界的具体形象的能力感兴趣。对他而言，科幻的关键贡献在于它重构了我们当代的体验，从关于未来世界的文本视角，将“现在”重塑为“过去”。科幻体裁的功能并非像人们有时想象的那样，也并非像大众新闻报道经常暗示的那样，预测未来，而是“使我们对自身当下的体验陌生化并重构” 。11对詹姆逊而言，科幻对未来的刻画展现的是我们乌托邦式想象力的萎缩，以及设想截然不同世界的困难——或许是不可能——而这矛盾地重新点燃了我们想象的能力，迫使我们直面失败，从而“出乎意料地转化为对我们自身绝对极限的沉思”。12与苏文一样，詹姆逊也知道科幻小说能够推动我们获得乌托邦式的洞见，以期纠正当今世界的问题。

Another influential academic conceptualization of sf comes from Fredric Jameson, who is equally interested in the genre’s capacity to offer concrete images of different, ideally better worlds. For him sf’s critical contribution is that it reframes the temporal experience of our contemporary moment, recasting the “present” as the “past” from the point of view of a text about the world to come. The genre’s function is not to predict the future, as people sometimes imagine and as popular journalism often implies, but rather “to defamiliarize and restructure our experience of our own present.”11 For Jameson, what sf figurations of the future demonstrate is the atrophied state of our utopian imagination, the difficulty—perhaps impossibility—of envisioning the radically other, which, paradoxically, reignites this capacity by forcing us to confront our failures and thus “becom[e] unexpectedly transformed into a contemplation of our own absolute limits.”12 Like Suvin, Jameson understands the capacity of sf to push us toward utopian insights that seek to correct the problems of the present world.

洞察我们习以为常的事物——以“异域”视角赋予事物新的视角——是科幻修辞能力的核心。尽管对该类型的实证研究与科幻必然会为边缘群体发声的希望相悖，但任何政治立场的科幻作品都源于这种变革的理念。如果我们考虑到科幻意象的激增，以及科幻与其他类型小说之间的界限逐渐模糊，这种倾向就不难理解了。例如，像《黑客帝国》（1999）这样一部在上映时就影响深远的电影，很容易被归类为科幻，因为它描绘了一个反乌托邦的世界，机器收割人类以获取化学能量，而我们却被困在一个模拟的矩阵中。快进到十多年后BBC播出的《黑镜》（2011-），该剧也提供了类似的关于媒介世界、人工智能和监控技术的叙述，这种数字身份和物质身份的模糊现在似乎反映了几乎日常生活，只是与现实世界略有偏差。进一步比较，我们可以考虑美国空军2010年代初的广告宣传活动，其口号是“这不是科幻小说；这是我们每天做的事情”，这是早期强调行动和冒险的口号的更新：“做一些惊人的事情”和“我们做不可能的事”。这种“科幻小说”的使用表明，由于其尖端技术，空军已经生活在未来。最后一个例子表明，科幻小说不再是未来主义小说，而更像是一幅理想的蓝图。

Seeing what we take for granted—the “alien” perspective that puts things in a new light—is central to sf’s rhetorical capacity. Although an empirical survey of the genre belies the hope that it inevitably gives voice to the marginalized, sf of any political persuasion emerges from this idea of change. This penchant is easily apprehended if we consider the proliferation of sf imagery as the lines between sf and other kinds of fiction blur. For example, a film such as The Matrix (1999), hugely influential upon its release, is easily categorized as sf, with its dystopian world of machines harvesting humans for their chemical energy while we remain obliviously trapped in a simulated matrix. Fast forward to the release of the BBC’s Black Mirror (2011–) just over a decade later, which offers similar narratives about mediated worlds, AI, and surveillance technologies, and this blurring of digital and material identities now appears as a reflection of almost-everyday existence, just slightly askew from the real world. Taking this comparison one step further, we might consider the US Air Force’s early 2010s advertising campaign under the slogan “It’s Not Science Fiction; It’s What We Do Every Day,” an update of earlier slogans that emphasized action and adventure: “Do Something Amazing” and “We Do the Impossible.” This use of “science fiction” suggests that the Air Force is already living in the future due to its cutting-edge technology. The last example sees sf evoked less as futuristic fiction and more as aspirational blueprint.

《黑镜》对数字化未来的反乌托邦式警告与美国空军对类似技术的颂扬形成鲜明对比，提醒我们科幻同样关乎可怕的噩梦和美好的梦想。如果一方面，它的影像激励我们取得更大成就，超越物质限制（这是一个常见的主题），那么另一方面，它警告我们社会变革带来的潜在后果——新技术在带来改进的同时，也会带来颠覆。詹姆逊认为，科幻让我们能够批判性地思考我们正在创造的未来，这与科学和文化变革同样相关。广告商将科幻与经济利润和增强型消费品的话语联系起来，利用科幻意象，使他们的产品看起来像是在引领科技故事所承诺的世界。例如，梅根·普雷林格的《另一部科幻小说》（2010）就完美地捕捉到了这一点，这是一部收录了20世纪中期未来主义广告意象的摄影选集。13与此同时，批判现状的活动家们也同样运用科幻技巧来表达对新世界的憧憬。诸如女性主义科幻（如今每年都会获得詹姆斯·蒂普特里奖）14和非洲未来主义（用于描述根植于非洲美学和经验的未来科幻作品）等备受推崇的传统，都基于这样一种信念：科幻帮助我们以全新的视角看待既定事实，从而挑战父权制、种族主义和其他不公正现象。15

The contrast between Black Mirror’s dystopian warnings about digitally mediated futures and the Air Force’s celebration of a similar technology reminds us that sf is equally about frightening nightmares and wondrous dreams. If on the one hand its images inspire us to achieve more, to transcend material limits (a frequent motif), then on the other it warns us of potential consequences that come with social change—that new technologies disrupt as much as they improve. Jameson’s notion that sf positions us to think critically about the future we are making is relevant equally to scientific and cultural change. Aligning sf with discourses of economic profit and enhanced consumer products, advertisers embrace sf imagery to make their products seem to usher in the world promised by technophilic stories. This is beautifully captured, for example, by Megan Prelinger’s Another Science Fiction (2010), a photo anthology of futuristic advertising imagery from the mid-twentieth century.13 At the same time, activists critical of the status quo draw equally on sf techniques to articulate visions of a new world. Celebrated traditions such as feminist sf, now honored annually by the James Tiptree Jr. Award,14 and Afrofuturism, a term used to describe sf works that envision futures rooted in African aesthetics and experience, are grounded on the belief that sf helps us see the given with new eyes, thereby to challenge systems of patriarchy, racism, and other injustice.15

截至撰写本文时，科幻小说已被许多实践社群广泛而多样地接受，他们往往出于截然不同的目的，并采用相应不同的美学和形式策略。随着女权主义者和非裔美国人对科幻小说的成功参与，其他边缘群体也将科幻小说视为重要的批判模式，包括土著科幻、拉丁裔科幻和亚洲侨民科幻。过去十年，有色人种作家的科幻作品显著增加，其中包括 NK 杰米辛、丽贝卡·罗恩霍斯、朱诺特·迪亚兹和特德·姜，仅举几例。活动家们也公开将科幻小说作为一种工具，以诸如《奥克塔维亚的育雏》 （2015）等作品为代表，该书由艾德里安·玛丽·布朗和瓦利达·伊玛里沙编辑，这是一本受科幻作家奥克塔维亚·E·巴特勒启发的活动家策略和新小说集；以及雪莱·斯特里比 (Shelley Streeby) 的《想象气候变化的未来》(Imagining the Future of Climate Change )，这本书重点介绍了环保活动家如何借鉴科幻小说的想象。16由同人研究学者亨利·詹金斯 (Henry Jenkins) 创立的“公民想象项目”记录了人们如何在作品中借鉴科幻文本，以表达对更美好世界的集体愿景和实践。17最近出版了一部新小说集《反抗：来自值得为之奋斗的未来的故事》 (2018)，作为一项筹款活动，所有收益都将捐给美国公民自由联盟 (ACLU)。

As of this writing, science fiction is widely and diversely embraced by many communities of practice, often to significantly divergent ends and with correspondingly different aesthetic and formal strategies. Following the success of feminist and African American engagement with the genre, other marginalized groups have turned to sf as a vital mode of critique, including Indigenous sf, Latinx sf, and Asian diasporic sf. The past decade has seen a significant increase in sf works by writers of color, among them N. K. Jemisin, Rebecca Roanhorse, Junot Díaz, and Ted Chiang, to name just a few. Activists are also overtly embracing sf as a tool, emblematized by works such as Octavia’s Brood (2015), edited by adrienne maree brown and Walida Imarisha, a book of activist strategies and new fiction inspired by sf author Octavia E. Butler; and by Shelley Streeby’s Imagining the Future of Climate Change, a book that highlights how environmental activists draw on sf imaginary.16 The Civic Imagination Project, founded by fan studies scholar Henry Jenkins, charts how people draw on sf texts in their work to articulate collective visions and practices for a better world.17 A recent collection of new fiction, Resist: Tales from a Future Worth Fighting Against (2018), was published as a fundraising effort, with all proceeds going to the ACLU.

科幻小说也日益成为一种全球性文学类型，在许多情况下，甚至被认可为一种全球性文学类型。为了全面地描绘科幻小说，安德鲁米尔纳借鉴世界体系理论，认为科幻诞生于启蒙运动与浪漫主义之间的文化辩证法，因此首先出现在工业化时期的欧洲国家。18抛开米尔纳关于创新和影响力的更宏大的论点，我想关注文化转向科幻与技术创新强化之间的关系。进入21世纪，随着世界越来越多的地区工业化、城市化，尤其是与全球信息和资本网络的联系日益紧密，我们看到推想小说在新的地区涌现。全球对科幻的热情，包括在中国、中东、拉丁美洲、韩国、印度及其他地区科幻传统的兴起，是该领域最令人兴奋的变化之一。许多网站致力于追踪和培育这些发展，而专注于推想文本的出版商Apex Book Company（成立于2004年）目前正在出版其“世界科幻”系列的第五卷，该系列将世界各地的故事翻译成英文。19

Science fiction is also increasing becoming—in many cases, becoming recognized as—a global genre. Attempting to comprehensively map what sf is or is not, Andrew Milner draws on world systems theory to argue that sf emerged from a cultural dialectic between Enlightenment and Romanticism, and thus appeared first in European countries as they industrialized.18 Setting aside Milner’s larger arguments about innovation and influence, I want to focus on this relationship between a cultural turn toward sf and the intensification of technological innovation. Into the twenty-first century, as more and more of the world becomes industrialized, urbanized, and especially linked into global networks of information and capital, we see speculative fiction emerge in new locations. The global embrace of sf, which includes the emergence of sf traditions in China, the Middle East, Latin America, Korea, India, and beyond, is among the most exciting ways the field is changing. Numerous websites are devoted to tracking and cultivating these developments, and the Apex Book Company (founded in 2004), a publisher focused on speculative texts, is now on the fifth volume of its World SF series, which translates stories from around the world into English.19

与Apex出版社合作的Rosarium出版社（成立于2013年）致力于推广科幻领域的多元文化传统，而2005年推出的在线科幻杂志《未来之火》（The Future Fire）则聚焦于社会和政治主题。世界科幻的蓬勃发展不仅将科技的广泛普及与科幻的吸引力联系起来，也揭示了盎格鲁科幻史上传统的守门人角色。颇具影响力的编辑们像坎贝尔这样的人在这一流派的发展过程中对它施加了限制，鼓励一些声音和观点，同时削弱其他声音和观点。这些声音往往是女性和有色人种的声音。20以前，编辑或其他行业看门人的控制是参与该领域的一大障碍，但在数字出版和按需印刷的时代，不同的社区可以建立自己的发行场所。如果这一流派一直拥抱如此多元化的声音，那么当我们听到科幻小说这个词时，我们脑海中浮现的可能是一组非常不同的画面。这些新声音的日益突出表明，21 世纪的科幻小说将与过去的科幻小说截然不同。

Joining Apex, Rosarium Publishing (founded in 2013) is dedicated to promoting a multicultural tradition in sf, while the online sf magazine The Future Fire, launched in 2005, focuses on social and political themes. As well as establishing a correlation between the widespread proliferation of technology and the appeal of sf, this burgeoning of world sf tells us something about traditional gatekeeping functions in the history of Anglo sf. Influential editors such as Campbell imposed restrictions on the genre as it developed, encouraging some voices and perspectives, while attenuating those of others. Often these were voices of women and people of color.20 Previously the control of editors or other industry gatekeepers was a barrier to participation in the field, but in an era of digital publishing options and on-demand printing, diverse communities can establish their own venues for distribution. Had the genre always embraced such pluralistic voices, we might have a very different set of images that spring to mind when we hear the term science fiction. The increased prominence of these new voices suggests that sf into the twenty-first century will be a very different thing from sf of the past.

在西方，科技对日常生活的改变也愈演愈烈，其标志是科幻文学与其他文学的融合日益加深，科幻场景在其他媒体（尤其是电子游戏）中占据主导地位。此外，科幻技巧也日益被业界视为一种工具，科技公司开始使用“科幻原型”和“设计小说”等术语来描述想象力和游戏在新产品开发中的重要性。大学开始开设“创新研究”课程，这些课程虽然并非严格意义上的科幻，但显然借鉴了科幻的策略和美学。我同意罗杰·勒克赫斯特的观点，他认为科幻作为一种可识别的形式出现于19世纪中后期，当时技术变革的步伐明显加快。一生中颠覆了社会规范。21从那时起，变革的步伐不断加快，我们越期待未来与现在的不同，科幻就越能成为一种主流文化形式。例如，亚利桑那州立大学科学与想象力中心等机构将自己定位为与产业界和艺术界平等对话，经常委托创作新小说来进一步探讨技术变革。22

The transformation of daily life by technology has intensified in the West as well, marked by the increased convergence of sf and other literatures and by the dominance of sf scenarios in other media, especially video games. Moreover, sf techniques are increasingly embraced as a tool in industry, with terms such as “sf prototyping” and “design fiction” being adopted by technology companies to describe the importance of imagination and play in the development of new products. Universities have begun to offer programs in “innovation studies,” which, while not strictly sf, clearly draw upon its strategies and aesthetics. I agree with Roger Luckhurst who argues that sf as an identifiable form appeared in the mid- to late nineteenth century, just as the pace of technological change visibly disrupted social norms within a lifetime.21 The pace of change has only accelerated since then, and the more we expect the future to differ from the present, the more sf becomes a dominant cultural form. For example, institutions such as Arizona State University’s Center for Science and the Imagination position themselves to speak equally to industry and to artistic communities, often commissioning new fiction to further conversations about technological change.22

在本书中，我将梳理当前关于科幻的批判性讨论，尤其是在科幻小说与当前科学技术研究领域交叉的背景下。我的主要目标是阐明科幻小说是科学研究学者希拉·亚萨诺夫所称的社会技术想象的延伸。她将社会技术想象定义为“集体持有、制度稳定、公开执行的对理想未来的愿景，这种愿景受到对社会生活形式和社会秩序的共同理解的驱动，而这些理解可以通过科学技术的进步实现，并支持科学技术的进步。” 23她承认科幻小说是此类愿景的一个载体，但我想指出，科幻小说还应做一些亟需做的事情——即批判性地审视谁是创造这些“共同理解”的集体的一部分。科幻小说关乎社会变革和技术变革，这有助于我们思考“科学技术的进步”是否也始终是公民和社会生活的进步。

In this book, I will map out the current critical discussion regarding science fiction, especially as the genre intersects with areas of current research in science and technology. My main goal is to demonstrate that sf is an extension of what science studies scholar Sheila Jasanoff calls the sociotechnical imaginary, which she defines as “collectively held, institutionally stabilized, and publicly performed visions of desirable futures, animated by shared understandings of forms of social life and social order attainable through, and supportive of, advances in science and technology.”23 She recognizes sf as one site of such visions, but I want to suggest that sf also does something more that is urgently needed—namely, it critically interrogates who is part of the collective creating these “shared understandings.” Social as well as technological change is at stake in sf, which helps us think through whether “advances in science and technology” are also always advances in civic and social life.

本书并非科幻史，亦非科幻综述，而是对该类型的选择性描述，如同一个思考当今社会生活中紧迫问题的工具包。我的例子主要取自近期出版的英文文本：我想强调科幻如何以及为何与当下的对话息息相关，我也意识到还有很多其他例子可供参考。对于那些对该类型历史以及关于科幻经典的争论感兴趣的读者，已经出版了一些优秀的科幻史著作，详见延伸阅读部分。这本小册子只能提供我在此概述的概念的说明性例子，而非科幻经典中所有重要文本的完整列表。事实上，我希望读者能够以此为基础，通过将科幻与来自更多实践社群的更广泛的文本进行对话，来补充和拓展我对科幻所能发挥的作用的理论。接下来的章节将探讨科幻与乌托邦传统的对话，它与殖民主义的关系，科幻如何成为思辨性设计的典范，它如何预见并回应当代机器人和基因组学等关键产业的创新，以及如何阐释塑造我们世界的两大社会力量——气候变化和投机性金融。如果我们生活在一个科幻世界，本书旨在帮助我们更准确地理解这意味着什么，并促使我们思考如何积极应对——而不是被动地等待——这个未来。

This book is neither a history nor a survey of sf, but a selective description of the genre as something like a toolkit for thinking through urgent issues in social life today. My examples will come predominantly from recent texts published in English: I want to highlight how and why sf is relevant to conversations at this moment, and I recognize that many other examples could be used. For those interested in a history of the genre and arguments about sf’s canon, excellent published histories are already in print as detailed in the further reading section. This short book can offer only illustrative examples of the concepts I outline here, not a full listing of every important text in the sf canon. Indeed, my hope is that readers build on this brief sketch, to fill in and augment my theorization of what sf can do by putting it in dialogue with a wider range of texts drawn from even more communities of practice. The chapters that follow look at sf’s dialogue with the utopian tradition, its relationship to colonialism, how sf has become the poster child for speculative design, how it has anticipated and responded to innovations in key contemporary industries of robotics and genomics, and how it illuminates two important social forces shaping our world, climate change and speculative finance. If we are living in a science fiction world, this book aims to help us articulate more precisely what that means and to prompt us to think about actively managing—rather than passively awaiting—this future.

2

2

乌托邦传统

The Utopian Tradition

科幻小说的核心在于想象世界原本的样子，这种对变革的渴望将科幻与乌托邦写作联系在一起。当我们思考科技如何改变日常生活时，两者的相似之处便显而易见。托马斯·莫尔的《乌托邦》虚构了岛屿文化，以此衬托当代英国的具体问题，例如圈地运动——剥夺农民的土地，为放牧羊群腾出空间——这种做法的动机源于英国制造业的技术变革，该变革导致英国的主要出口产品从原毛转向了羊毛布。因此，生活某个领域的转变——生产优质布料的技术能力——所产生的影响远远超出了布料的质量或生产效率。乌托邦写作正是通过这种联系和后果来运作的：它想象一个可能由不同历史事件引发的“他乡”。并通过描写与日常生活的对比，促使读者理解物质世界的可塑性。

At its core, science fiction is about imagining how the world might be otherwise, and this impulse toward change connects sf to utopian writing. Their similarity becomes clear when we consider how science and technology change daily life. Thomas More’s Utopia invented its fictional island’s culture as a foil to specific problems in contemporary England, including enclosures that dispossessed peasants of their land to make way for grazing sheep, a practice motivated by technological shifts in English manufacture that changed their main export from raw wool to woolen cloth. Thus, a shift in one area of life—the technological capacity to produce good cloth—had consequences that extend far beyond the cloth’s quality or the efficiency of its manufacture. Utopian writing works through such connections and consequences: it imagines an elsewhere that might result from different historical contingencies and uses the contrast between its depictions and ordinary life to prompt readers to understand the material world as malleable.

当然，乌托邦作品表达了超越科学发展所导致的差异的变革需求，而经典作品中的关键作品以其政治愿景而非科学推断而闻名。同样，科幻小说也包含对差异进行广泛想象的作品，这些差异不仅包括新的科学范式或发明，还包括组织日常生活、理解性别或种族等社会类别以及组织劳动力和财富分配的新方式。苏文思考这种乌托邦模式，认为科幻文本与现实主义不同，“不仅是对现实的反映，也是对现实的诠释” 。1

Utopian works articulate a need for change beyond differences caused by scientific development, of course, and key works in the canon are renowned for their political visions more than for their scientific extrapolations. Science fiction, similarly, encompasses works that imagine difference capaciously, not only new scientific paradigms or inventions, but also new ways of organizing daily life, of understanding social categories such as gender or race, and of organizing labor and the distribution of wealth. Thinking of this utopian mode, Suvin argues that sf texts, in contrast to realism, are “not only a reflecting of but also on reality.”1

乌托邦写作通过将其描述与日常生活进行对比，促使读者理解物质世界是可塑的。

Utopian writing uses the contrast between its depictions and ordinary life to prompt readers to understand the material world as malleable.

莫尔的“乌托邦”一词在英语中具有双重含义：既有“u-topia”（乌托邦，意为“没有地方”），也有“eu-topia”（乌托邦，意为“好地方”）。评论家们争论着，包括莫尔原著在内的具体标题究竟是真正想要代表理想的替代方案，还是仅仅讽刺了普通世界以及旨在立法建立完美社会的专制主义计划。莫尔的“乌托邦”有很多值得钦佩的地方：它组织合理，没有私有财产，犯罪率低，生产力高，没有死刑，也没有对财富的非理性追求（黄金被嘲笑）。然而，关于“乌托邦”，我们也或许应该提出一些质疑，例如它对奴隶劳动及其婚姻习俗，这些习俗严惩婚前性行为，并允许新娘和新郎在签订合同之前全裸地审视他们未来的伴侣。莫尔作品的第一部分以虚构的莫尔和拉斐尔·希斯洛德之间的对话写成。希斯洛德是一位环球旅行家，他向来宾们讲述了他在旅途中见到的不同社会的故事。希斯洛德指出，所有习俗，如果用不同文化的社会规范来看待，都会显得怪异，甚至疯狂。这种“透过外星人的眼睛看世界”的视角，将成为科幻作品的核心工具之一。

More’s Utopia played on the double meaning of the Latinate word when pronounced in English: both u-topia, no place, but also eu-topia, good place. Critics debate whether specific titles, including More’s original, truly intend to represent ideal alternatives or if they function as satires of both the ordinary world and the authoritarian project of legislating a perfect society. There is much to admire about More’s Utopia: it is rationally organized, with no private property, little crime, great productivity, no capital punishment, and no irrational pursuit of wealth (gold is regarded with derision). Yet there are things about Utopia we may wish to question as well, such as its use of slave labor or its marriage customs, which severely punish premarital sex and allow brides and grooms to review their proposed partner fully naked before committing to the contract. The first part of More’s work is written as a dialogue between a fictionalized More and Raphael Hythloday, a world traveler who regales the company with tales of diverse societies he has seen on his travels. Hythloday points out that all customs seem bizarre, even insane, to someone looking at them through the social norms of a different culture, a version of “seeing through alien eyes” that will become one of the central tools in sf’s repertoire.

莫尔的作品中还有许多其他前往奇异新世界的航行，其中一些描绘了前往月球或更远地方的旅行，例如开普勒的《梦境》、弗朗西斯·戈德温的《月中人》（1638），以及大鼻子情圣的《另一个世界》三部曲，该三部曲分别设想了月球（1657）、太阳（1662）和群星上的生命（最后一卷已佚失）。2玛格丽特·卡文迪什的《炽热的世界》（1666）因其展现当代女性对科学的兴趣而引人注目。这部冒险故事描述了一个可以通过北极到达的另一个世界（天空中有不同的星星），讲述了一个年轻女子在前往这个世界后成为领导者，并最终组织探险队返回征服她原来的世界的故事。与许多十七世纪的作品一样，《炽热的世界》探讨了当时新的哲学思想和新的感知尺度。在欧洲文化中兴起，并伴随着引发科学革命的创新研究方法。3它最初与卡文迪什的《实验哲学观察》一起印刷，后者批判了她同时代人罗伯特·波义尔和罗伯特·胡克等人著作中机械论自然观的核心观点。4

More’s work is joined by numerous other voyages to strange new worlds, including some that imagine travel to the moon or beyond such as Kepler’s Somnium, Francis Godwin’s The Man in the Moone (1638), and Cyrano de Bergerac’s L’Autre Monde trilogy that imagined life on the moon (1657), the sun (1662) and the stars (this last volume has been lost).2 Margaret Cavendish’s The Blazing World (1666) is noteworthy for its demonstration of contemporary women’s interest in science. Describing another world (the sky has different stars) that can be accessed via the North Pole, this adventure narrative tells of a young woman who becomes a leader after traveling to this world and eventually organizes an expedition back to conquer her original world. Like many seventeenth-century works, The Blazing World engaged with the new philosophical ideas and new scales of perception then emerging in European culture, alongside innovative methods of research that gave rise to the Scientific Revolution.3 It was originally printed with Cavendish’s Observations upon Experimental Philosophy, a critique of the mechanist view of nature central to the work of her contemporaries Robert Boyle and Robert Hooke, among others.4

随着这种向不同世界讲述故事的传统逐渐扎根，世界上最古老的科学机构——皇家学会于1660年获得了特许状。由此，我们见证了现代科学世界观与科幻写作传统的兴起。弗朗西斯·培根的乌托邦作品《新亚特兰蒂斯》（1627年）描绘了基于科学发现和技术官僚治理的理想化人类未来愿景，并设想了一个名为“所罗门之家”的研究机构，我们可以将其作为皇家学会本身的典范。在这些早期的乌托邦世界中，科学技术的创新与更好的治理和经济繁荣齐头并进。工业革命之后，随着技术变革的步伐达到新的顶峰，我们看到了乌托邦作品的又一次繁荣。后来的传统关注的是改善技术进步带来的社会弊病。技术进步与资本主义紧密相连，因此忽视了对挤在城市贫民窟的工人、因缺乏安全标准而受伤的工人以及遭受污染性工业健康后果的工人的关注。社会主义乌托邦，例如爱德华·贝拉米的《回顾：2000-1887》和威廉·莫里斯的《乌有乡的消息》（1890）想象的未来以经济革命为前提，根植于集体所有权以及物质收益与人类幸福之间的平衡。

As this tradition of narrating tales to different worlds took hold, the Royal Society, the world’s oldest scientific institution, was granted a charter in 1660. We thus see the modern, scientific worldview emerging alongside a tradition of writing that would become sf. Francis Bacon’s utopian work, New Atlantis (1627), which portrays an idealized vision of human futures based on scientific discovery and technocratic governance, envisioned a research collective, Solomon’s House, that we might take as a model for the Royal Society itself. In these early utopian worlds, innovations in science and technology go hand-in-hand with better governance and economic prosperity. Following the Industrial Revolution, when the pace of technological change reached a new peak, we see another flourishing of utopian works. This later tradition was concerned with ameliorating the social ills that came with technological progress that was wedded to capitalism and thus unchecked by concern for the lives of workers crowded into urban slums, injured by a lack of safety standards, and suffering the health consequences of polluting industries. Socialist utopias, such as Edward Bellamy’s Looking Backward: 2000–1887 and William Morris’s News from Nowhere (1890), imagined futures premised on economic revolutions, rooted in collective ownership and a balance between material gains and human happiness.

这些社会主义乌托邦为小说形式带来了一项更重要的创新。旅行者们探索的理想社会与读者的家乡并非地理上的距离，而是时间上的距离。在每一部作品中，主人公都会沉睡，醒来后发现自己身处一个焕然一新的世界。这种形式促使读者更加执着地想象从他们的世界通往新世界的道路，如果他们采纳小说所推崇的价值观，这一转变便触手可及。19世纪也延续了地理上错位的乌托邦传统，其创作基础是18世纪的讽刺传统（塞缪尔·巴特勒的《埃勒璜》 [1872]），吸收了当时的科学思想（爱德华·布尔沃-利顿的《未来的种族》 [1871]），或质疑传统的性别角色（玛丽·E·布拉德利·莱恩的《米佐拉》 [1890]）。

These socialist utopias introduced a more important innovation to the form. Their travelers explored ideal societies distanced from the reader’s home not by geography but by time. In each, the protagonist falls asleep to awaken in a world transformed. This form prompts its readers to envision even more insistently the path from their world to the new one, a transformation within reach were they to adopt the values admired by the fiction. The nineteenth century also continued the tradition of geographically displaced utopias, building on an eighteenth-century tradition of satire (Samuel Butler’s Erewhon [1872]), taking up recent scientific ideas (Edward Bulwer-Lytton’s The Coming Race [1871]), or questioning conventional gender roles (Mary E. Bradley Lane’s Mizora [1890]).

进入20世纪，作家们将社会讽刺与对世界如何改变的憧憬相结合，并经常探讨科学的哲学含义。这类文本后来被归类为20世纪20年代根斯巴克命名的独特体裁。赫伯特·乔治·威尔斯的《时间机器》（1895年）将进化论的投射与对阶级分化的尖锐批判相结合，以全新的视角将科技（而非睡眠）想象为主人公体验未来的方式，而不仅仅是体验一百年后的未来。数年后，却已是数十万年后。夏洛特·珀金斯·吉尔曼的《她乡》（1915）或许是最著名的女权主义乌托邦，它既描绘了一个女性不受父权制束缚的世界，也批判了以女性与生俱来的脆弱性为前提的当代医学科学。5 20世纪70年代，女权主义科幻小说的爆发，与第二波女权运动相呼应，继续构想女性专属社会或性别隔离社会，有时被视为女性自由的乌托邦空间，有时则被视为女权主义者批判的现存非理性性别隔离的反乌托邦式强化。

Into the twentieth century, writers combined social satire with visions of how the world could be transformed, often engaging with the philosophical implications of science. Such texts were later categorized as part of the distinct genre named by Gernsback in the 1920s. H. G. Wells’s The Time Machine (1895) combines evolutionary projection with a harsh critique of class division, newly imagining technology (rather than sleep) as a way for his protagonist to experience the future not merely one hundred years hence, but hundreds of thousands of years later. Perhaps the best-known feminist utopia, Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s Herland (1915) is both a vision of a world where women are not constrained by patriarchy and an argument against contemporary medical science premised on the inherent weakness and fragility of women.5 The explosion of feminist science fiction in the 1970s, in dialogue with the second-wave feminist movement, would continue to imagine women-only societies or gender-segregated societies, sometimes as utopian spaces of women’s freedom, other times as dystopian intensifications of existing, irrational gender segregation that feminists critiqued.

“反乌托邦”一词用来形容比现有世界更糟糕的世界，始于20世纪中期，用于描述那些通过强化当代世界最具破坏性的趋势，从而引发社会批判的叙事。在赫伯特·乔治·威尔斯的《沉睡者觉醒》 （1910）中，他笔下的沉睡者醒来后，并非置身于先前作品中的乌托邦，而是面对着一个挥霍了社会主义梦想承诺、建立了压迫性财阀统治的未来。6一些最著名且至今仍具有影响力的科幻作品源自这一传统，包括奥尔德斯·赫胥黎的《美丽新世界》（1932）和乔治·奥威尔的《一九八四》（1949）。俄罗斯小说家叶夫根尼·扎米亚京的《我们》 （1921）是一部讽刺极权主义的作品，虽然名气不如扎米亚京大，但同样震撼人心，并且对奥威尔产生了直接影响。这些反乌托邦的奠基之作汲取了……关注技术在极权社会中所扮演的角色，从扎米亚京和奥威尔作品中无处不在的监视，到赫胥黎作品中通过操纵胚胎来产生不同种姓的工人。

The term dystopia to describe worlds worse than the existing one began to be used in the mid-twentieth century for narratives that enacted social critique by intensifying to their logical ends the most damaging tendencies of the contemporary world. In H. G. Wells’s The Sleeper Awakes (1910), his sleeper awakens not to the utopias of previous texts, but to a future that has squandered the promise of the socialist dream and established an oppressive plutocracy instead.6 Some of the best-known and still influential works of sf come from this tradition, including Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World (1932) and George Orwell’s Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949). Russian novelist Yevgeny Zamyatin’s We (1921), a satire of totalitarianism, is less famous but equally powerful and was a direct influence on Orwell. These foundational dystopian works draw attention to the role that technology plays in totalitarian societies, from the omnipresent surveillance in Zamyatin’s and Orwell’s works, to the manipulation of embryos to produce distinct castes of workers in Huxley’s.

进入二十一世纪，反乌托邦传统超过了乌托邦传统，这一事实有时令人惋惜。这种不平衡现象更加严重，因为现在的科幻文本比以前更受欢迎，尤其是改编成电影和电子游戏的科幻文本，获得了大批追随者。随着近年来极右政治的复苏，批判极权主义的中世纪作品如《一九八四》重新流行起来，而根据青少年 (YA) 小说改编的电影系列如《饥饿游戏》（2012-2015 年）则大获国际成功。当今反乌托邦小说最有趣的事情之一是它在青少年小说市场上的主导地位。这类文本中许多最受欢迎的都是推测性的，它们通常描绘反乌托邦世界：仅举几例，尼尔·舒斯特曼的《Unwind dystology》（2007-2015 年），这是他偏爱的称呼这个系列的术语；米拉·格兰特的《新闻快讯》系列（2010-2016 年）；保罗·巴奇加卢皮的《破船者》系列（2010-2017 年）和《怀疑工厂》（2014 年）；科利·多克托罗的《小弟弟》 （2008 年）和《国土安全》 （2013 年）；玛丽·卢的《传奇》三部曲（2011-2013 年）；更不用说那些因电影改编而广为人知的作品，如《分歧者》（2014-2016 年）、《移动迷宫》 （2014-2018 年）和《黑暗心灵》（2018 年）。7

The dystopian tradition outpaces the utopian one into the twenty-first century, a fact sometimes lamented. The disproportion is intensified because sf texts are much more widely embraced now than they were in the earlier periods, especially in film and videogame adaptations that gain a large following. With the recent resurgence of extreme right politics, midcentury works critiquing totalitarianism such as Nineteen Eighty-Four are newly popular, while film series such as The Hunger Games (2012–2015), based on young adult (YA) novels, are massive, international hits. One of the most interesting things about dystopian fiction today is its dominant position in the YA fiction market. Many of the most popular among such texts are speculative, and they generally depict dystopian worlds: to name only a few, Neal Shusterman’s Unwind dystology (2007–2015), his preferred term for this series; Mira Grant’s Newsflash series (2010–2016); Paolo Bacigalupi’s Shipbreaker series (2010–2017) and The Doubt Factory (2014); Cory Doctorow’s Little Brother (2008) and Homeland (2013); Marie Lu’s Legend trilogy (2011–2013); not to mention those more widely known due to film adaptations, such as Divergent (2014–2016), The Maze Runner (2014–2018), and The Darkest Minds (2018).7

这类青少年作品回应了21世纪日益加剧的经济差距、两极分化且常常充斥着种族主义言论、迫在眉睫的气候变化以及不确定的就业前景等日益增长的不稳定性。反乌托邦小说的流行，为即将步入成年的一代人发出了声音，而他们正处在一个普遍对未来感到悲观的时代，尽管这些作品并不一定认同这种观点。鉴于科学曾一度与压迫性的政治力量沆瀣一气，其中许多作品表达了对科学伦理的担忧：优生学曾授权未经同意的绝育；种族主义科学曾试图为奴隶制辩护，并在被俘的非裔美国人身上进行实验；医学与保险和制药行业之间妥协的交集；以及军事和监控技术的历史。这类作品描绘的未来是：老年人掠夺年轻人，试图榨取或以其他方式剥削年轻人的活力；或者，它们被设定在一个种族和经济隔离加剧的未来警察国家，而更具侵入性的监控工具则使这种隔离更加严重。

Such YA works respond to the increasing sense of precariousness in a twenty-first century of intensified economic disparity, polarizing and often racist rhetoric, looming climate change, and uncertain prospects for employment. The embrace of dystopian fiction gives voice to a generation who will enter adulthood during a time of widespread pessimism about the future, although these texts do not necessarily capitulate to this view. Many of them express concerns about the ethics of science given a history in which science has at times been complicit with oppressive political forces: eugenics that authorized sterilization without consent; racist science that attempted to rationalize slavery and experimented on captive African American populations; medical science’s compromised intersection with insurance and pharmaceutical industries; and a history of military and surveillance technologies. Such texts depict a future in which the old prey upon the young, seeking to extract or otherwise exploit young people’s vitality, or they are set in a future police state of heightened ethnic and economic segregation, enabled by more invasive surveillance tools.

乌托邦想象在二十世纪中后期的衰落，与一种类似的感觉有关，即社会状况稳步恶化而非改善（大多数早期科幻小说的轨迹）。共产主义革命演变为极权主义国家所带来的失望，对帝国成就的重新评估鉴于殖民地独立运动和其他反种族主义行动，以及对科学进步的承诺导致核毁灭的无时不在的威胁和大规模环境破坏的恐惧，许多人得出结论，乌托邦主义往好了说是无可救药的天真，往坏了说是同谋。8这种转向悲观主义的观点也许最好地体现在原子弹爆炸后迅速出现的核战争末日故事中。内维尔舒特的《海滩》（1957 年）描绘了澳大利亚最后一批人类的最后时光，由于 1959 年的热门电影改编而成为其中最著名的作品。其他几篇文本也毫不畏惧地得出结论，人类面临灭绝的危险，包括莫迪凯罗斯瓦尔德的《第七层》（1959 年），讲述了一个旨在帮助精英等待辐射的地下设施不可避免地失败的故事；海伦·克拉克森（Helen Clarkson）的《最后一天》（The Last Day ，1959 年）被不公正地忽视，该书对辐射致死的各个阶段给出了令人不安的准确描述；朱迪思·梅里尔（Judith Merril）的《炉边的影子》（Shadow on the Hearth，1950 年）是一部从家庭而非军事角度看待战争的小说。9

The waning of the utopian imagination through the mid- to late twentieth century is linked to a similar sense that social conditions have steadily become worse rather than better (the trajectory of most early sf). The disappointment as communist revolutions turned into totalitarian states, the reassessment of imperial achievements in light of colonial independence movements and other anti-racist activism, and the horror that the promises of scientific advance resulted in the ever-present threat of nuclear annihilation and massive environmental damage led many to conclude that utopianism was hopelessly naïve at best, complicit at worst.8 The turn toward pessimistic visions is perhaps best embodied by nuclear war apocalypse stories that quickly followed in the wake of the atomic bomb. Nevil Shute’s On the Beach (1957), depicting the last days of the final humans in Australia, is the best known among them due to the popular film adaptation in 1959. It was joined by several other texts that unflinchingly concluded that humanity risked extinction, including Mordecai Roshwald’s Level 7 (1959), about the inevitable failure of an underground facility intended to help the elite wait out radiation; Helen Clarkson’s unjustly neglected The Last Day (1959), which gave disturbingly accurate descriptions of the stages of death by radiation; and Judith Merril’s Shadow on the Hearth (1950), a novel that views the war from a domestic rather than a military point of view.9

自二十世纪中叶以来，直截了当的乌托邦作品相对匮乏，这可以用一种普遍的观点来解释：二十世纪是一场持续不断的灾难。许多作家和思想家彻底反对乌托邦理想，提出了被称为“反乌托邦”的愿景——即旨在讽刺……的作品。一种特定的乌托邦愿景或整个乌托邦主义项目。乌托邦主义与科幻小说交叉领域的重要理论家汤姆·莫伊兰 (Tom Moylan) 认为，在此类批判之后，一种新的“批判性乌托邦”出现在 20 世纪 60 年代和 70 年代。批判性乌托邦通过创造更具辩证性的愿景来回应这种悲观主义，这些世界展示了他们“对乌托邦传统局限性的认识”，但同时仍然致力于一个更美好世界的理想，将乌托邦视为一种愿望或梦想。10莫伊兰将诸如欧内斯特·卡伦巴赫的《生态乌托邦》 (1975)之类的作品称为“批判性乌托邦” ，这是一种可持续生活方式的反主流文化愿景；乔安娜·拉斯的杰作《女性男人》（1975 年）对性别意识形态对女性主体性的影响进行了深入探讨，讲述了“同一个”女人在具有不同性别规则的平行世界中四次迭代的故事；厄休拉·勒古恩的《一无所有》（1974 年）的副标题为“模棱两可的乌托邦”，对比了两个世界，一个主要是资本主义，另一个是无政府主义，以思考每个世界在自由和稳定方面为个人提供了什么；塞缪尔·德拉尼的《特里顿的麻烦》（1976 年）回应了勒古恩的观点，副标题为“模棱两可的异托邦”，关注的是一个人，由于他对本质化性别认同的主观投入，他对所谓的乌托邦式的流动性别认同自由感到不满。

The relative absence of straightforwardly utopian works from midcentury on can be explained by this widely shared view that the twentieth century was an ongoing disaster. Many writers and thinkers turned against the ideal of utopia altogether, offering visions dubbed “anti-utopia”—that is, works that are intended to satirize either a specific vision of utopia or the entire project of utopianism altogether. Tom Moylan, a key theorist of the intersection of utopianism with sf, argues that in the wake of such critiques a new kind of “critical utopia” emerged in the 1960s and 1970s. Critical utopias respond to this pessimism by creating more dialectical visions, worlds that demonstrate their “awareness of the limitations of the utopian tradition” but at the same time remain committed to the ideal of a better world, to utopia as a desire or dream.10 Moylan names as “critical utopias” works such as Ernest Callenbach’s Ecotopia (1975), a countercultural vision of sustainable lifeways; Joanna Russ’s masterful The Female Man (1975), a complex exploration of the consequences of gender ideology on female subjectivity, which follows four iterations of the “same” woman as she develops on parallel worlds with distinct gender rules; Ursula K. Le Guin’s The Dispossessed (1974), subtitled “An Ambiguous Utopia,” which contrasts two worlds, one mainly capitalist, the other anarchist, to consider what each offers the individual in terms of freedom and stability; and Samuel R. Delany’s Trouble on Triton (1976), responding to Le Guin with the subtitle “An Ambiguous Heterotopia,” which focuses on an individual who is made unhappy by the putatively utopian freedom to occupy fluid gender identities given his subjective investment in essentialized gender identity.

正如这篇简短的调查所表明的，这类作品强调了实现乌托邦的困难，并给理想的独特性，正是这种理想的早期迭代形式所特有的。莫伊兰使用“批判性”一词的方式与文化理论家在提及批判理论时的方式相同，即批判性地进行批判，而非像反乌托邦那样简单地进行否定。他还区分了“乌托邦蓝图” 11（在许多十九世纪乌托邦中冗长乏味地展示的完整计划）与詹姆逊在其奠基性论文（收录于《未来考古学》（2007）12 ）中所说的“乌托邦是一种欲望或冲动”的概念。这些著作承认，乌托邦永远不会完结，任何世界格局都将永远包含差异，而不是遵循某些理想化的规则，因此任何真正的乌托邦都将是动态的，并不断变化。这种关于乌托邦主义的思维模式也与欧内斯特·布洛赫的《希望的原则》（三卷本，1954-1959）息息相关，这本书对苏文的科幻定义产生了深远的影响。许多科幻研究都探讨了这种与乌托邦主义的联系，而埃里克·史密斯的《全球化、乌托邦与后殖民科幻小说》（2012）和菲利普·韦格纳的《可能性的冲击波》（2014）等新作则继续论证这种关系是构成性的，尽管其使用的标准与苏文不同。13

As this brief survey indicates, such works foreground the difficulties of achieving utopia and put pressure on the singularity of the ideal that characterized earlier iterations of the form. Moylan uses the term “critical” in the way that cultural theorists use it when referring to critical theory, that is, as engaged in critique, not simply the negation like the anti-utopia. He also differentiates between a notion of “utopia as blueprint,”11 the fully worked-out plan so tediously on display in many nineteenth-century utopias, and what Jameson would come to call utopia as desire or impulse in his foundational essays, collected in Archaeologies of the Future (2007).12 These works acknowledge that utopia is never finished, that any configuration of the world will always continue to include difference rather than conform to some idealized rule, and thus any true utopia will be dynamic, open to continual change. This mode of thinking about utopianism is also connected to Ernest Bloch’s The Principle of Hope (3 vols, 1954–1959), which was a formative influence on Suvin’s definition of sf. Much of the scholarship on sf explores this connection to utopianism, and new works such as Eric Smith’s Globalization, Utopia and Postcolonial Science Fiction (2012) and Philip Wegner’s Shockwaves of Possibility (2014) continue to argue that this relationship is constitutive, albeit using different criteria than did Suvin.13

莱曼·塔尔·萨金特回应莫伊兰关于批判性乌托邦的理念，提出了“批判性反乌托邦”的概念。他指出，反乌托邦文本并非简单地表达了对未来的绝望，而是努力警告我们警惕这些可怕的未来。反乌托邦警告我们情况可能变得更糟，其中蕴含着这样的信念：只要做出更好的选择，我们或许就能避免这些噩梦。14乌托邦和这种批判性反乌托邦——不同于反对变革的反乌托邦主义——都源于这样一种信念：对未来图景的情感反应有助于实现特定的未来。许多近期的反乌托邦作品，尤其是那些面向青少年读者的反乌托邦作品，都展现了这种特质，这让我们能够理解，这种模式的盛行与其说是对未来的绝望，不如说是激励年轻人塑造未来，而不是局限于强化当前的轨迹。

Responding to Moylan’s idea of the critical utopian, Lyman Tower Sargent argued for the category of the “critical dystopia.” He observes that dystopian texts do not simply voice a lack of hope for the future, but instead work to warn us against these frightening futures. Dystopia, as a warning that things can get worse, contains the seeds of believing that with better choices we might avoid these nightmares.14 Both utopia and this kind of critical dystopia—as differentiated from anti-utopianism, which is anti-change—emerge from the belief that affective response to images of the future helps to bring specific futures into being. Many recent dystopias, especially those directed to a YA audience, demonstrate this quality, enabling us to understand the prevalence of this mode less as a sign of despair about the future and more as a spur for young people to shape their futures toward something other than an intensification of present trajectories.

反乌托邦警告我们事情可能会变得更糟，它包含着这样的信念：只要做出更好的选择，我们就可以避免这些噩梦。

Dystopia, as a warning that things can get worse, contains the seeds of believing that with better choices we might avoid these nightmares.

批判性乌托邦或反乌托邦的框架强调那些提出问题而非提供答案的作品，它们通常探索社会世界的多种形态。它们往往避免追求完美或纯粹的政治，认识到培育异质社群的复杂性和难度。通过突出共谋与妥协、谈判与斗争等问题，这类作品引导读者参与批判性思考和选择，而不是试图将这些读者吸引到任何特定未来愿景的阵营中。乌托邦传统中的辩证法作品通常与一些社会运动相关，这些运动认为科幻小说是推动变革的有力工具，例如女权主义、酷儿行动主义和反种族主义斗争。乔安娜·拉斯的《像女人一样写作》（1995）对科幻传统中大部分性别歧视进行了尖锐的批判，并解释了她和她的许多同时代人选择科幻来表达女性摆脱父权制的愿景的原因。15非裔美国科幻传统早在被归类为非洲未来主义之前就已存在，最著名的非裔美国科幻作家之一奥克塔维亚·巴特勒因其探讨实现包容和公正社区的难度的作品而闻名。16在Sun Ra、George Clinton、DJ Spooky 和 ​​Afrika Bambaattaa 等音乐家和表演艺术家的作品中，我们经常看到植根于非洲文化形式和价值观的乌托邦未来，约翰·阿孔法拉的短片《历史的最后天使》（1996 年）精彩地捕捉到了这一点，这部纪录片访谈与科幻框架相结合，探索了非洲技术的被埋没的历史。这部电影的影响是黑人科幻美学传统在加奈儿·梦奈、埃里卡·巴杜等艺术家的作品中得以延续的原因之一。

The frameworks of critical utopia or dystopia foreground works that ask questions instead of providing answers, often exploring multiple configurations of social worlds. They often avoid politics of perfection or purity, recognizing the complexity and difficulty of fostering heterogeneous communities. In foregrounding questions of complicity and compromise, negotiation and struggle, such works engage their readers in projects of critical thinking and choice rather than try to win these readers as recruits to any particular vision of the future. Dialectical works within the utopian tradition are often connected to social movements that have found sf a potent tool for change, such as feminism, queer activism, and anti-racist struggles. Joanna Russ’s To Write Like a Woman (1995) offers a trenchant critique of the sexism of much of the sf tradition alongside the reasons why she and many of her contemporaries embrace sf to articulate visions of women’s freedom from patriarchy.15 A tradition of African American sf existed long before it was categorized as Afrofuturism, and one of the most celebrated African American sf authors, Octavia Butler, is justly famous for works that interrogate the difficulty of achieving an inclusive and just community.16 In the work by musicians and performance artists such as Sun Ra, George Clinton, DJ Spooky, and Afrika Bambaattaa that was crucial to developing Afrofuturist sensibility, we often see utopian futures rooted in African cultural forms and values, brilliantly captured in John Akomfrah’s short film, The Last Angel of History (1996), a mix of documentary interview and sf frame that explores a buried history of African technology. The impact of this film is among the reasons why a tradition of Black sf aesthetics continues in work by artists such as Janelle Monáe, Erykah Badu, and others.

除了类型写作之外，那些试图塑造未来集体愿景的人常常会转向科幻意象，这是参与乌托邦主义的另一种方式。技术创新与进步的修辞融合与类型科幻的出现同时出现。从这个角度来看，我们可以将诸如水晶宫（1851年万国工业博览会的举办地）以及世界博览会的传统视为更宏大的科幻世界的一部分。文化话语。这类博览会将科学新成就的展示与公众娱乐相结合，象征着对科技的敬畏之情，这种敬畏之情也体现在低俗科幻小说中。1939年纽约世界博览会，题为“明日世界”，以科幻推测与奇妙未来之间的这种密切关系为前提，并被当时刚刚起步（且主要仍为美国）的科幻迷选为首届世界科幻大会的举办地。17 20世纪60年代的太空竞赛同样受到科幻小说中乐观的太空飞行和未来人类星空居住愿景的影响。这些也是科幻小说的乌托邦维度，尽管它们对当时在印刷科幻中盛行的对“善”的反思性追问明显不那么感兴趣。

Beyond genre writing, those seeking to shape collective visions of the future often turn to sf imagery, another way to participate in utopianism. The rhetorical conflation of technological innovation with progress writ large emerged alongside genre sf. From this point of view, we can see things like the Crystal Palace, home to the 1851 Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations, and the tradition of World’s Fairs as part of a larger sf cultural discourse. Combining displays of the wonders newly accomplished by science with public entertainment, such fairs emblematized the sense of wonder about technology also conveyed by especially pulp sf. The 1939 New York World’s Fair, The World of Tomorrow, was premised on this intimate relationship between sf speculation and a wondrous future and was chosen as the location for the first ever World Science Fiction Convention by a fledgling—and largely still American—sf fandom.17 The Space Race of the 1960s was similarly strongly influenced by optimistic sf visions of spaceflight and future human residence in the stars. These, too, are utopian dimensions of sf, although decidedly less interested in the reflexive interrogation of “the good” that was taking hold in print sf.

如今，人们对载人火星探测及其最终殖民的热情，体现了这种技术官僚科幻乌托邦主义精神依然鲜活存在——但同时也与其反乌托邦的阴影深刻交织。埃隆·马斯克雄心勃勃的SpaceX计划，包括商业航天的承诺，以及受人尊敬的科学家斯蒂芬·霍金关于人类除非进入太空“没有未来”的宣言，将科学事实与科幻小说、乌托邦承诺与反乌托邦威胁的暗示混杂在一起。18在其科学新闻著作《人类的未来》 （ 2018 ）中，加来道雄热情洋溢地阐述了我们的科技实力将如何使人类——不同于其他物种——摆脱……通过超越我们生物学、生态系统和地球的极限，我们能够避免灭绝的必然性。19加来道雄以通俗科幻小说的紧迫激情进行写作，但他的愿景无疑是可行的，甚至是必要的未来。他的超越愿景会让很多人觉得是反乌托邦的，而不是充满希望的，这提醒我们乌托邦思想的模糊性和复杂性，即每一个完美未来的模型（对某些人来说）对另一些人来说都是一场抹杀的噩梦。达米恩·查泽雷的电影《登月第一人》（2018）戏剧化地改编了尼尔·阿姆斯特朗首次登月的历史，当电影以蓝调歌手吉尔·斯科特-赫伦的口语表演“月球上的白人”作为配乐时，这些利害关系就变得清晰起来——这首歌尖锐地批评了在非裔美国人社区仍然贫困的情况下资助航天的选择。20乌托邦和反乌托邦的愿景都是修辞工具包的重要组成部分，它为科幻小说在乌托邦文化中的各种呈现方式提供了信息。

Today, the recent enthusiasm for manned missions to Mars and its eventual colonization exemplify how this spirit of technocratic sf utopianism remains alive and well—yet also deeply in dialogue with its dystopian shadow. Elon Musk’s ambitious SpaceX program, including the promise of commercial spaceflights, and the pronouncement by respected scientist Stephen Hawking that the human race “has no future” unless it goes to space, promiscuously mix science fact with science fiction, utopian promise with the hint of dystopian threat.18 In his science journalism book, The Future of Humanity (2018), Michio Kaku rhapsodizes about how our technological prowess will enable humans, unlike other species, to escape the inevitability of extinction by transcending the limits of our biology, our ecosystems, and our planet.19 Kaku writes with the urgent passion of pulp sf but presents his visions as unquestionably plausible, indeed, as necessary futures. His vision of transcendence will strike many as dystopian rather than promising, reminding us of the ambiguities and complexities of utopian thinking, that every model of a perfect future (for some) will be a nightmare of erasure for others. Damien Chazelle’s film First Man (2018), dramatizing the history that led to Neil Armstrong’s first moon walk, makes these stakes starkly clear when it features blues singer Gil Scott-Heron’s spoken-word performance “Whitey on the Moon”—an acerbic critique of the choice to fund spaceflight while African American communities remain impoverished—in its soundtrack.20 Both utopian and dystopian visions are an important part of the rhetorical toolkit that informs the range of ways that sf is taken up across utopian cultures.

3

3

未来学与思辨设计

Futurology and Speculative Design

第二章探讨了科幻与为社会批判而想象其他世界的悠久传统的关系，以及在此基础上建立的科幻研究学术框架。然而，在大众的想象中，科幻与雨果·根斯巴克开创的通俗杂志传统是同义词。每年由世界科幻小说协会（一个全球科幻迷组织）成员投票选出的最佳科幻成就的雨果奖，以他的名字命名。然而，在成为这一新兴文学流派的主要推动者之前，根斯巴克曾热情地参与了许多旨在尽快引领科技化未来的项目，并在《科学美国人》、 《现代电气》和《电气实验者》等刊物上发表文章。后两本杂志分别于1908年和1913年由他创办和编辑。在《事物的反常性》（2016）中，格兰特·怀索夫 (Grant Wythoff) 是根斯巴克 (Gernsback) 关于新兴技术、修补和专利申请、广播监管以及无线电广播和电视前景的著作汇编，他认为“根斯巴克所理解的科幻项目”是他推广通信技术的延伸，开创了“一种思考和与新兴媒体互动的方式” 。1

Chapter 2 looks at sf’s relationship to a long tradition of imagining other worlds for purposes of social critique and at academic frameworks for studying sf that have built on this foundation. In the popular imagination, however, sf is synonymous with the pulp magazine tradition pioneered by Hugo Gernsback. The Hugo Awards that honor the best sf achievements annually, voted on by members of the World Science Fiction Society, a global fan organization, are named for him. Yet before he gained fame as the chief promoter of this new literary genre, Gernsback was enthusiastically involved in a number of projects that aimed to usher in the technologized future as quickly as possible, publishing essays in venues such as Scientific American, Modern Electrics, and The Electrical Experimenter, the latter two of which he founded and edited, in 1908 and 1913, respectively. In The Perversity of Things (2016), a compendium of Gernsback’s writings on emergent new technologies, tinkering and patent seeking, broadcast regulation, and the promises of wireless radio and television, Grant Wythoff argues that “the project of science fiction as Gernsback understood it” was an extension of his promotion of communication technologies, pioneering “a way of thinking about and interacting with emerging media.”1

以此方式重新构建，我们可以绘制出一幅不同的二十世纪科幻史。这一历史对科幻小说作为一种新的审美模式（或许能促使我们以不同的方式看待社会世界）的兴趣有所减弱，而更关注科幻小说所描述的奇特手段或场景如何很快成为物质存在的一部分。需要明确的是，我并非认为哪种框架对于描述这一类型“更好”或“更真实”；而是试图凸显对“科学”和“虚构”的强调之间的张力，认为这种张力对于塑造当今被认可为科幻的文本范围至关重要。本章从根巴克对小说的兴趣入手，他认为小说是一种工具，可以促进人们理解和接受不断变化的媒体格局所提供的新可能性，并追溯科幻小说的另一个谱系，将这一类型与未来学等社会实践联系起来。正如 Wythoff 所言，Gernsback 对当时新兴的广播电视技术的热情，以及他从虚构和实践的角度思考这些技术对世界变革的影响的渴望，对于经历过类似历史的 21 世纪读者来说，是十分熟悉的。互联网和其他社交媒体技术发展的转型时期。

Reframed in this way, we can chart a different history of sf through the twentieth century, one less interested in science fiction as a new aesthetic mode that might prompt us to see our social world differently and more focused on how the strange devices or scenarios sf describes may soon be part of material existence. To be clear, I am not suggesting that either framing is “better” or “truer” for describing the genre; rather I seek to foreground this tension between an emphasis on “science” and an emphasis on “fiction” as central to shaping the range of texts recognized as sf today. Beginning with Gernback’s interest in fiction as a tool to promote the understanding and embrace of the new possibilities afforded by a changing media landscape, this chapter traces another genealogy of sf that connects the genre to social practices such as futurology. As Wythoff suggests, Gernsback’s enthusiasm for then-emergent technologies of radio and television and his desire to think about their world-transforming effects in both fictional and practical ways is familiar to twenty-first-century readers who have lived through a similarly transformative period in the development of the Internet and other social media technologies.

《全能》、《连线》甚至《大众机械》等杂志都将有关新科学突破的文章、考虑其经济或政治影响的社论以及科幻小说和电影的评论混合在一起。他们也经常发表新小说。最有可能进入《大众机械》等杂志“十大”科幻小说榜单的作品通常与获得雨果奖的作品截然不同，也与获得文学气息更浓厚的奖项（如《轨迹》或《奇异地平线》）的作品不同，这反映了科幻小说的多重理想以及构成这一流派的相关实践团体。除了根斯巴克对新兴媒体技术的兴趣之外，第一代科幻迷与火箭俱乐部的成员有很多重合，他们尝试火箭发射，并通过小说来想象未来的星际旅行。2将富有远见的叙述与实际的修补相结合，体现了根斯巴克对广播和科幻小说的贡献，并且在本世纪后期得到了第一代个人电脑和同样热情的一代实践者的响应，他们接受了这项新技术以及受其启发的故事。

Magazines such as Omni, Wired and even Popular Mechanics mix articles on new scientific breakthroughs with editorial pieces considering their economic or political implications and with reviews of sf fiction and film. They also frequently publish new fiction as well. The sf titles most likely to make a “top 10” list in a magazine such as Popular Mechanics are often very different from those awarded Hugos and different again from those receiving accolades in more literary venues such as Locus or Strange Horizons, reflecting the multiple ideals of sf and the related communities of practice that constitute the genre. In addition to Gernsback’s interests in emerging media technology, the first generation of sf fans overlapped significantly with those involved in rocketry clubs, who experimented with rocket launches and used fiction to imagine a coming future of interplanetary travel.2 This mix of visionary narrative with practical tinkering exemplified Gernsback’s own contributions to radio and sf, and would be echoed later in the century with the first generation of personal computers and an equally enthusiastic generation of hands-on experimenters who embraced both this new technology and stories inspired by it.

著名科学杂志《自然》承认，富有想象力的推测在科学史和政策制定讨论中占有一席之地。 从 1999 年开始出版原创短篇科幻作品，最初是作为反思千禧年的项目，但从 2005 年开始成为《自然》杂志“未来”栏目的常规栏目；最近，它开设了未来条件博客，允许对故事及其背后的科学发表评论。在线文化评论杂志Slate最近与亚利桑那州立大学的科学与想象力中心合作推出了未来时态，该杂志出版的原创小说关注新兴技术的变革性影响；每部新小说都会附上相关研究和行业人士的评论。再举一个例子，麻省理工学院出版社，这家隶属于美国第一所专门研究科学和技术的学术机构的大学出版社，自 2013 年以来出版了十二个明天选集，精选原创小说关注近未来技术的潜在影响。

Acknowledging that imaginative speculations have their place in scientific histories and in discussions regarding policy making, the preeminent science journal Nature began to publish short original works of sf in 1999, initially as a project to reflect on the turn of the millennium, but adopted as a regular feature, Nature’s “Futures,” beginning in 2005; more recently, it started the Future Conditional blog to allow commentary on the stories and the science behind them. The online cultural commentary magazine Slate has recently partnered with ASU’s Center for Science and the Imagination to offer Future Tense, which publishes original fiction focused on the transformative effects of emergent technologies; each new work of fiction is published alongside a response by someone involved in related research and industry. To list just one more example among many, MIT Press, the university press affiliated with America’s first academic institution specializing in science and technology, has since 2013 published the Twelve Tomorrows anthologies, curating original fiction focused on the potential impacts of near-future technologies.

这些不同的项目延续了根斯巴克创办科普和科幻杂志的初衷，尤其是他的编辑工作和读者来信论坛，为读者创造了一个社群和交流的空间。在此后的一百多年里，科技的文化地位，尤其是大多数人在日常生活中对其基础设施和设备的依赖程度，发生了巨大的变化，这主要得益于信息技术和全球化贸易的推动。对话关于自动驾驶汽车或无现金未来，关于人工智能助手或转基因食品，这些话题并非仅仅关注一小部分人，他们有先见之明地专注于工程和工业领域，而这些领域正是根斯巴克所探讨的世界的特征。相反，这些话题是主流关注的焦点，就像未来一样，无论是雄心勃勃的硅谷创业者们对此充满热情，还是卡车司机对无人驾驶汽车带来的失业感到恐惧。虽然根斯巴克不得不在转瞬即逝的廉价杂志的读者来信版面进行他的对话，但如今，这类对话的场所资金充足，已成为主流，而这得益于根斯巴克及其同时代人所略知一二的技术变革。从20世纪80年代信息时代伊始，到21世纪社交媒体技术的兴起，人们对近未来技术的兴趣已成为主流，而科幻小说正处于这场充满想象力和社会变革的中心。这一类型的作用以io9之类的网站为代表，其副标题为“我们来自未来”。该网站一部分内容是科幻媒体评论，一部分内容是新兴技术观察，一部分内容是科学与政治交汇的思考。这类网站以及类似的平台正是新一代科幻作品的诞生地。

These various projects continue what Gernsback began in founding both popular science and sf magazines, and especially with his editorial work and letters forums that created a space of community and exchange among his readers. In the one hundred plus years since, the cultural status of technology and especially the degree to which most people rely on its infrastructure and devices in daily life has changed dramatically, propelled mainly by information technologies and globalized trade. Conversations about self-driving cars or cashless futures, about AI assistants or GMO foods, are not subjects that concern only a small group, presciently focused on engineering and industry, conditions that characterized the world Gernsback addressed. Rather, such topics are mainstream concerns, as is the future, whether anticipated with fervor by aspiring Silicon Valley entrepreneurs or regarded with dread by the truck driver anticipating the loss of work due to driverless vehicles. While Gernsback had to stage his conversations in the letters pages of ephemeral pulp magazines, the venues for such conversations today are well-funded and mainstream, enabled by the very technological transformations only fleetingly glimpsed by Gernsback and his contemporaries. From the beginning of the information age in the 1980s, and intensifying with social media technologies into the twenty-first century, interest in near-future technologies has become a mainstream obsession, and sf is at the center of this imaginative—and social—transformation. The genre’s role is emblematized by websites such as io9, subtitled “We Come from the Future,” which is one part sf media reviews, one part emergent technology watch, and one part reflections on intersections of science and politics. This and similar venues are where a new generation of sf is being invented.

如今，科幻无疑是多媒体的产物，电影、电视、漫画和数字游戏都受到与印刷品同等的关注。许多当代对话由一些机构培育，例如过去十年在几所大学设立的创新研究项目。其中许多机构明确地将其工作框架与科幻性紧密相连，例如亚利桑那州立大学的科学与想象力中心或牛津大学的人类未来研究所。虽然许多此类研究项目不愿被贴上“科幻”的标签，但它们专注于以富有想象力的方式思考技术，强调未来（尤其是不远的将来），并关注新发明或新的科学范式将如何改变日常生活，这些都是科幻小说所关注的。诚然，从事创新研究的人对其推断的合理性以及所用数据的范围和来源有着更严格的标准，但与科幻作家一样，他们也试图理解假定的技术变革将带来的一系列错综复杂的结果。

Today sf is unquestionably a multimedia affair, and all of film, television, comic books, and digital games are discussed with the same attention paid to print. Many contemporary conversations are cultivated by institutions, such as programs in innovation studies established over the last decade at several universities. Many of them explicitly frame their work in ways clearly linked to science fictionality, such as ASU’s Center for Science and the Imagination or the Future of Humanity Institute at the University of Oxford. While many of these research initiatives would not wish to embrace the label “science fiction,” their focus on thinking imaginatively about technology, their emphasis on the future, especially the near future, and their interest in how daily life will be changed by new inventions or new scientific paradigms are all preoccupations shared by sf. True, those working in innovation studies hold themselves to a more rigorous standard regarding the plausibility of their extrapolations and the scope and provenance of the data they use, but like sf authors they seek to understand the entangled set of outcomes that will flow from a postulated technological change.

当然，也存在差异：创新研究通常优先考虑经济和基础设施变革，试图预测创新将如何颠覆常规，并向企业（有时是政府）提供建议，告诉他们如何为这些转变做好准备，从而确保盈利能力；另一方面，科幻小说则更关注创新将如何改变个人及其社区，这当然可能当然，也包括工作机会的变化。举一个具体的例子，查看《国际创新研究杂志》的目录，创新研究与科幻传统之间的联系显而易见。在撰写本文时，最新上传的论文是关于增材制造的，即3D打印，其中物体是通过沉积的“打印”材料逐层构建的。与许多科幻故事一样，本文展望了未来此类技术可用于打印活体组织，并探讨了与此类技术相关的市场机会。3

There are differences, too, of course: innovation studies often prioritizes economic and infrastructure change, trying to anticipate how innovations will disrupt business-as-usual and to advise corporations—and sometimes governments—on how to prepare for these transformations and thus ensure profitability; sf, on the other hand, tends to be more interested in how an innovation will change individual humans and their communities, which may, of course, include changes to the availability of work. To give just one concrete example, connections between innovation studies and sf traditions are evident when looking at the table of contents of the International Journal of Innovation Studies. At the time of this writing, the most recently uploaded paper is about additive manufacture, that is, 3D printing in which the object is built layer by layer from “printed” material deposited. Like many sf stories, this article looks to a future when such techniques can be used to print living tissue, as it considers market opportunities related to such technologies.3

如果我们转向科幻小说，我们首先想到的可能是《星际迷航》中的复制器，以及尼尔·斯蒂芬森（Neal Stephenson）的《钻石时代》（1995）中的物质编译器。这些文本设想，如果所需物品能够按需打印，社会组织将会有怎样的变化。在这两种情况下，终结稀缺经济学造成的苦难都是关键，这表明科幻小说的取向与创新研究截然不同。如果我们想回顾3D打印技术在物质层面而非幻想层面上出现时出版的科幻作品，我们或许可以参考威廉·吉布森（William Gibson）的《边缘》（The Peripheral，2014）或金·斯坦利·罗宾逊（Kim Stanley Robinson）的《极光》（Aurora，2015）：在前者中，3D打印被用于制造药物（包括药品和非法药物），这对医疗保健的可及性和执法工作产生了影响；在后者中，它是实现跨代太空旅行的策略之一，因为人们无需提前预估所有所需物品。在这里3D打印的存在并非像之前的例子那样，使这个世界与我们的世界截然不同的新鲜事物，但我们仍然看到科幻作家对这项技术可能带来的改变进行了更广阔的思考。科幻思维鼓励颠覆，并欢迎对不同未来的开放性；创新研究通常致力于最小化变化，或者至少试图引导创新，以确保现有的权力动态得以持续。

If we turn to sf, we might think first of Star Trek’s replicator or later the matter compiler in Neal Stephenson’s The Diamond Age (1995), texts imagining how social organization might be different if needed items can be printed on demand. In both cases, ending the suffering caused by economics of scarcity is key, showing how sf’s orientation remains distinct from that of innovation studies. If we want to look at sf works published when 3D printing was a material possibility rather than an imagined fantasy, we might turn to William Gibson’s The Peripheral (2014) or Kim Stanley Robinson’s Aurora (2015): in the former, 3D printing is used to make drugs, pharmaceutical and illegal, with implications for health-care access and law enforcement; in the latter, it is one of the strategies that makes intergenerational space travel achievable, as one need not anticipate in advance every needed item. Here the existence of 3D printing is not the novelty that makes this world different from our own, as in the earlier examples, but nonetheless we see sf authors thinking more capaciously about the changes such technology could entail. Science fictional thinking fosters disruption and welcomes the openness of a different future; innovation studies is often interested in minimizing change, or at the very least it seeks to channel innovation to ensure power dynamics already at play persist.

从这一比较中，我们可以得出两个重要的观察结果。首先，叙事和想象力在多大程度上被认为是应对当代世界的重要工具，而当代世界的特点是快速变化和普遍依赖技术。其次，科幻小说与科学之间存在着某种联系，尽管这种联系并非简单地幻想科幻小说能够启发电视、通信卫星、机器人劳动甚至互联网等特定发明，所有这些发明在科幻小说中都有先例，其出现的时间早于其物质化。相反，正如科林·米尔本在《可修改的未来》一书中所论述的那样，我们可以将科学家参与科幻小说的方式类比为科幻迷的实践，即在与他们所喜爱的科幻作品对话的过程中，创造他们自己的意义，通常是他们自己的文本和艺术。4他认为，科学家同样以三种方式从科幻小说中汲取灵感：蓝图，试图将小说中想象的事物具体化；补充，使用替代技术来实现小说所达到的目标。科学；以及推测，小说可以启发未来的研究。在《自然》杂志的“未来”或“未来时态”等平台中，科幻创作者与科学家之间的对话受到关注，这表明想象力发挥的作用比以往人们所认识到的更大，它既促进了科学创新，也帮助科学家思考实验室之外的研究。这也是科学与广大公众相遇的地方，创新成为复杂世界的一部分，用吉布森在《Omni》杂志上首次发表的一篇故事中令人回味的短语来说，“街道会找到事物自身的用途。” 5

Two important observations emerge from this comparison. The first is the degree to which narrative and the imagination are recognized as important tools for negotiating a contemporary world characterized by rapid change and a pervasive reliance on technology. The second is that there is a relationship between science fiction and science, albeit not the simple fantasy that science fiction inspired specific inventions such as television or communication satellites or robotic labor or even the Internet, all of which have precursors in sf that predate their material emergence. Instead, as Colin Milburn argues in “Modifiable Futures,” we might think of how scientists engage sf as analogous to fan practices of making their own meanings, often their own texts and art, in dialogue with the sf they love.4 He argues scientists similarly draw from sf in three ways: blueprints, which seek to materialize something imagined in the fiction; supplements, that use alternative technologies to accomplish an end achieved by fictional science; and speculations, where the fiction inspires future research. The interest in fostering dialogue between sf creators and scientists in venues such as Nature’s “Futures” or “Future Tense” acknowledges that the imagination has played a larger role than has been previously acknowledged, both in fostering scientific innovation and in helping scientists think about their research beyond the laboratory. This is also where science and the larger public meet, when innovations become part of a complex world in which, to use Gibson’s evocative phrase from a story first published in Omni magazine, “the street finds its own uses for things.”5

科幻小说和科学之间存在着某种联系，尽管并不是科幻小说启发了具体的发明这种简单的幻想。

There is a relationship between science fiction and science, albeit not the simple fantasy that science fiction inspired specific inventions.

事实上，Sheila Jasanoff 在引言中引用的社会技术想象概念源于她的信念：科学技术研究学者对想象力在塑造科学实践史以及公众如何理解和回应科学方面所发挥的作用关注不足。她认识到“想象力是一种社会实践”，6她将科幻小说视为丰富的社会技术想象来源，这些想象与科学家共同催生了现代生活的具体政策、技术和生活方式。她的目标是“探究科学技术如何通过各种社会行为主体的想象力工作，融入到对集体利益的多元愿景的演绎和生产中，并将治理规模从社区扩展到民族国家，直至整个地球” 。7许多许多研究科学与流行文化交叉领域的学者关注科幻文化与研究文化之间的这种交流，他们经常强调虚构文本如何成为一种速记手段，被记者和科学家所利用，因为他们试图将人们对虚构文本的感受与研究议程联系起来——对太空竞赛所培育的美好未来的梦想，或对与克隆和转基因食品相关的可怕创造物的恐惧。通过研究纳米技术研究的历史，米尔本提出了一种概念化他所称的“纳米视觉”的具体方法，这种方法依靠思辨性语言和未来主义修辞来构成其研究领域。8大卫·柯比从略微不同的角度认为，科幻电影的科学顾问经常参与他所谓的“叙事原型设计”，这是一个在想象一种可能的技术的物质形式时变得更有趣和更具思辨性的机会。9

Indeed, Sheila Jasanoff’s notion of sociotechnical imaginaries cited in the introduction comes from her conviction that science and technologies studies scholars have paid insufficient attention to the role of the imagination in shaping both the history of scientific practice and how the public has understood and responded to science. Recognizing that “imagination is a social practice,”6 she cites sf as a rich source of sociotechnical imaginaries that have coproduced, with scientists, the specific policies, technologies, and lifeways of modern life. Her aim is “to investigate how, through the imaginative work of varied social actors, science and technology become enmeshed in performing and producing diverse visions of the collective good, at expanding scales of governance from communities to nation-states to the planet.”7 A number of scholars working at the intersections of science and popular culture focus on such exchanges between sf and research cultures, often emphasizing how fictional texts become a shorthand, drawn upon by both journalists and scientists, as they seek to connect the feelings people have about a fictional text to a research agenda—the dream of glorious futures cultivated by the Space Race, or fear of monstrous creations associated with cloning and GMO foods. Examining the history of nanotech research, Milburn theorizes a specific way of conceptualizing what he dubs “nanovision” that relies on speculative language and futuristic rhetoric to constitute its field of study.8 From a slightly different point of view, David Kirby argues that science advisors to sf film often engage in what he calls “diegetic prototyping,” a chance to be more playful and speculative as they imagine the material form of a possible technology.9
